Replace.Text: ------------------------------------[NEWLINE]领袖名称 -- 斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]领袖特性 - 国民教育委员会[NEWLINE]在标准速度下，建造剧院广场+100% [ICON_Production] 建造速度。剧院广场建筑以及著作可提供+2 [ICON_Science] 科技值。解锁科技“金属铸造”后可训练特色单位枪骑兵。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]特色单位 - 枪骑兵[NEWLINE]斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世作为领袖时的文艺复兴时期特色轻骑兵单位，取代骑兵。夹击时获得 [ICON_Strength] 战斗力加成。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]领袖议程 - 周四晚餐[NEWLINE]喜欢 [ICON_Culture] 文化产出高的文明。尽可能多地招募伟人，尊重同样这么做的文明。不喜欢忽视伟人的文明。
斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世
周四晚餐
喜欢 [ICON_Culture] 文化产出高的文明。尽可能多地招募伟人，尊重同样这么做的文明。不喜欢忽视伟人的文明。
（您招募了很多伟人）
斯坦尼斯瓦夫对你们在艺术和科学领域的杰出贡献印象深刻。
（您的文化产出很高）
斯坦尼斯瓦夫对你们文化的进步感到高兴。
（您只招募了一小部分伟人）
斯坦尼斯瓦夫为你对伟人的傲慢感到失望。
联邦的贵族人民选举你，波尼亚托斯基家族的斯坦尼斯瓦夫作为他们的新国王。你现在的任务是：在古老的自由原则和对公众的未来启蒙的需要之间寻求平衡。向你身边的人传播知识和文化，你的后代一定会视你如奥古斯都一样伟大！
国民教育委员会
在标准速度下，建造剧院广场+100% [ICON_Production] 建造速度。剧院广场建筑以及著作可提供+2 [ICON_Science] 科技值。解锁科技“金属铸造”后可训练特色单位枪骑兵。
斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世
波兰国王，立陶宛大公
欲要确定，必先怀疑。

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Stanislaw Antoni Poniatowski was born on 17 January 1732 to Stanislaw Poniatowski and Konstancja (née Czartoryska) Poniatowska. The Poniatowski family was among the highest-situated of the Polish nobility. He was educated by his mother, then by private tutors, including Russian ambassador Herman Karl von Keyserling. He did not have many friends in his teenage years; instead, he developed a fondness for books, which continued throughout his life. He made his first foreign voyage to Western Europe in 1748, when he accompanied the Russian army as it advanced to Germany.

Poniatowski owed his career to his family connections with the powerful Czartoryski family and their political faction, known as Familia. The Familia sent him in 1755 to Saint Petersburg in the service of Charles Hanbury Williams, who had been named British ambassador to Russia. In Saint Petersburg, Poniatowski met Catherine Alexeievna (the future empress Catherine the Great). The two became lovers. Poniatowski had to leave St. Petersburg twice, in July 1756 and August 1758 due to court intrigue.

Upon the death of Poland's King Augustus III in October 1763, negotiations began concerning the election of the new king. Catherine threw her support behind Poniatowski. The Russians spent about 2.5m rubles supporting his election, Poniatowski's supporters and opponents engaged in some military posturing and even minor clashes, and in the end, the Russian army was deployed only a few miles from the election sejm. In the end, there were no other serious contenders, and during the convocation sejm on 7 September 1764, the 32-year-old Poniatowski was elected king, with 5,584 votes.

During the Sejm (Polish for "Parliament" or "Assembly") in October 1766, Poniatowski attempted to push a radical reform, restricting the disastrous liberum veto policy. He was opposed by conservatives, who were supported by the Prussian and Russian ambassadors. Abandoned by the Familia, Poniatowski's reforms failed to pass. Meanwhile, some factions now rallied under the banner of the Bar Confederation, aimed against the dissidents, Poniatowski and the Russians. After an unsuccessful attempt to find allies in Western Europe, Poniatowski and the Familia had no choice but to rely more heavily on the Russian Empire, which treated Poland as a protectorate. Faced with the weakness of Poland and continuing chaos, Austria, Russia and Prussia decided to intervene militarily, in exchange for significant territorial concessions from the Commonwealth. Although Poniatowski protested the First Partition of the Commonwealth in 1772, he was powerless to do anything about it.

Eventually Poniatowski and the Sejm acceded to the partition treaty; at the same time, several other reforms were passed. Royal power was restricted. The Sejm created two notable institutions: the Permanent Council, a main governmental body in continuous operation, and the Commission of National Education. The partitioners intended the Council to be easier to control than the unruly Sejm, and indeed it remained under the influence of the Russian Empire. Nevertheless, it was a significant improvement in the Commonwealth governance. The new legislation was guaranteed by the Russian Empire, giving it another excuse to interfere in Commonwealth politics if the legislation it favored was changed.

In the context of the wars being waged against the Ottoman Empire by both the Austrian Empire and the Russian Empire, Poniatowski tried to draw Poland into the Austro-Russian alliance. Ultimately, the Polish-Russian alliance was not implemented. However, in the ensuing Four-Year Sejm of 1788–92 (known as the Great Sejm), Poniatowski threw his lot with the reformers and co-authored the Constitution of 3 May 1791. The Constitution introduced sweeping reforms. Poniatowski himself described it, according to a contemporary account, as "founded principally on those of England and the United States of America, but avoiding the faults and errors of both, and adapted as much as possible to the local and particular circumstances of the country."

Shortly thereafter, conservative Polish nobility formed the Targowica Confederation to overthReplace the Constitution, which they saw as a threat to the traditional freedoms and privileges they enjoyed. The confederates aligned themselves with Russia's Catherine the Great, and the Russian army entered Poland, marking the start of the Polish–Russian War of 1792, also known as the War in Defense of the Constitution. The Sejm voted to increase the Polish Army to 100,000 men, but due to insufficient time and funds this number was never achieved. Poniatowski's attempts at negotiations with Russia proved futile. On 24 July 1792, Poniatowski joined the Targowica Confederation. Despite, or because of, changing sides, Poniatowski had not saved the Commonwealth. He and the reformers had lost much of their influence, both within the country and with Catherine. Neither were the Targowica Confederates victorious. To their surprise, there ensued the Second Partition of Poland. Faced with his powerlessness, Poniatowski considered abdication; in the meantime he tried to salvage whatever reforms he could.

Poniatowski's plans were ruined by the anti-Russian Kosciuszko Uprising. The king did not encourage it, but once it began he supported it, seeing no other honorable option. Its defeat marked the end of the Commonwealth. Poniatowski tried to govern the country in the brief period after the defeat of the Uprising, but on 2 December 1794, Catherine demanded that he leave Warsaw, a request to which he acceded on 7 January 1795, leaving the capital under Russian military escort and settling briefly in Grodno. On 24 October 1795, the act of the final, Third Partition of Poland was signed; one month and one day later, on 25 November, Poniatowski signed his abdication. He died after a stroke on 12 February 1798.
斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世领导下的波兰和缓地将文化、科技与军事杂糅到一起，同时依靠她的人民来推动科技与文化发展，即使前路未知，依然步伐坚定。

与雅德维嘉的领袖能力类似，斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世可从每座城市的军营中获益：除了所谓周围单元格的加成以外，每建造完成一个军营将随机免费获得一个尤里卡。以此类推，每建造完成一个剧院广场将随机免费获得一个鼓舞。对文化与军事的强调不应阻止科技的进步，因为斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世可使每个文化类建筑都能产出少量科技值。若资源缺乏，则波兰的特色建筑与国际贸易路线加成将会使生产力与金币的增长变得相对容易。中期游戏时，国家保卫任务则交给特色单位枪骑兵，一种高机动性的轻骑兵单位，且在形成夹击时会对敌人造成更多伤害。整体游戏风格应偏重于城市与区域的精心经营，最好每个城市都有商业中心、剧院广场和军营。如此将会为整场游戏的均衡发展提供坚实基础，从而指引您选择一种合适的胜利条件。
欢迎，欢迎，尊贵的客人！桌子刚刚摆好。我是斯坦尼斯瓦夫，这个王国的守护神。
你愿意和我一起去我的宫殿花园逛逛吗？我向你保证，那是一个远离世俗的地方。
太棒了！我的使臣随后就到，他们会多加关注你的领地。
我建议我们交换一下各自首都的情况。我们有很多东西要互相了解。
你好，尊贵的客人。
我亲自欢迎你们的代表，他们将被安置在最好的住处。
我的人民不希望外国干涉，我拒绝你的代表团。
我已派特使到你的首都，带着我们最好的山鸡和调味酒。我相信你会喜欢的。
我和议会都同意。
我还没有得到议会批准来同意这一协议。
我国人民对开放边界协定很感兴趣，他们希望旅行和探索更广阔的世界。
我完全同意。我一直打算提出这一提议。
不行，现在还不是时候。
你已经与我们友好相处很久了，我们应该向世界宣布我们的友谊。
谢谢，真的谢谢你！
我理解，但这仍让我很难过。
联邦表示有兴趣在这个变幻莫测的世界上找到一个坚定和值得信赖的盟友。你愿意成为其中一员吗？
我的宫门永远向你这样开明的人敞开。
你吓到我的孔雀了，你这个无知的畜生，快离开我的草坪。
如果你以为你可以肆意挥舞你的马刀，而我的人民却不会起来反抗，那你就大错特错了。
{LOC_DIPLO_ACCEPT_DECLARE_FRIEND_FROM_AI_LEADER_JFD_FREDERICK_ANY}
{LOC_DIPLO_REJECT_DECLARE_FRIEND_FROM_AI_LEADER_JFD_FREDERICK_ANY}
这可不行。你背信弃义的消息很快就会以小册子的形式广泛传播。
我再也不能容忍你卑鄙的行为了。我已经没有耐心了。[NEWLINE]（谴责你）
（您只招募了一小部分伟人）
要这样吗？那我要在议会上提议提高战争征税。
议会宣布我们国家进入战争状态，做好觉悟吧。
议会已经同意批准我们两国之间的和平条约。
议会永远不会接受这种侮辱性的条款，战争应当继续下去。
我们的国家厌倦了战争。让我们放下武器，重建家园。
我失败了，这顶王冠归你了。
{LOC_DIPLO_DEFEAT_FROM_AI_LEADER_JFD_STANISLAW_ANY}
枪骑兵
斯坦尼斯瓦夫二世作为领袖时的文艺复兴时期特色轻骑兵单位，取代骑兵。夹击时获得 [ICON_Strength] 战斗力加成。

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Uhlan was a Polish light cavalry unit armed with lances, sabres, and pistols which came to frequent the armies of 18th and 19th century Russia, Prussia, and Austria. Descendents of the Tartar settlers of Lithuania, the first Uhlan regiment was created by the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in the early 1700s. Swift and unobstructed by the cumbersome armor which had previously dominated mounted warfare, the Uhlan quickly grew in popular use for their versatility and speed; able to conduct reconnaissance, skirmishes, or to head-on charges. Today, a ceremonial regiment of Uhlans is retained by the Polish Armed Forces.
+{1_Amount}战斗力 来自于形成夹击
